body:
First of all - I'm fresh off the boat and love what I'm seeing here - the open algorithms are a great idea and I'm relieved that the user base is somewhat conscious of how too much politics on the front-page can be off-putting 😘👌.

But having been made a social media refugee for the nth time - and having seen so many subs I loved get taken over by SRS and destroyed; reddit alternatives become unsavoury distilled versions of what they replace; entire discord communities just vanish with no explanation; I'm becoming like one of those refugees with PTSD who is having trouble feeling secure in whatever host country he ends up in.

I think eventually social media will end up decentralised, with users' streams hosted and replicated by some kind of blockchain magic - the streams intersecting and aggregating using users' own algorithms and filters; where the websites that users visit are mere gateways to the network; and this will stop any bad actors being able to ban users or communities: if one site falls, all the content will still be available from another.

But until that approach becomes viable - is there any guarantee that ruqqus won't just pull the plug a month before the next election, or start doing devious things as financial pressure increases and they need to please financiers - or as the webmasters' ideological views change? If not a technical guarantee then some kind of legal one?

Apologies if this has been asked already but it's a tricky one to search for.

body:
No. In fact there's already a cabal of sorts forming. They're very benevolent, but there's no promises it will stay that way and it's still unfair to other users. I warned them that this is the same stuff that killed reddit and the admins need to be much more careful about their favoritism.

I find it likely that they will stop this soon, but if not then Ruqqus will eventually end up like Reddit and Digg did, although we've probably got some years before the first signs of death begin to show. Either way there's no promises, as things usually go an entirely new direction once they get popular, ironically killing what made it popular in the first place.
